div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor end Manager - R. SNELLING. Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. SATURDAY. NOVEMBER 17, 1906.
The journals learn from Tangier that Rais- oli has submitted to the Sultan a police pr ject for the region of Tangier and Mogador, making him do away with French and Spanish officers. (HAVAS)

The effective ruler of Morocco is still Raisoli. He has settled himself in Aizila, where he is hunting for lost property and restoring confidence, and has announced that be will not leave till be is formally appointed Bash. Meanwhile in Tangier his men have constituted themselves the guardians of order, and arrest prisoners without the sanction of the Mahkzan officials. Last Saturday week they seized the p imp-house of the Spanish Electric Light Company, who had refused to pay them blackmailed and plunged the town into darkness, —an act in flagrant violation of all treaties. On the following Monday the French Cruiser Galilee arrived at the harbour, and when her launch attempted to land it was bombarded with stones by the mob. Lawlessness in Morocco his evidently reached a climax. The Saltan's officials are powerless t) restrain either Baisnli or the mob. Riisnli his authority, but exercises it for illegitimate purposes, while the mob, as in the Galilee incident, are being allowed to cultivate their anti foreign proclivities. It is clearly incumbent on France and Spain, whose ships are now lying at Tangier, to take immediate steps to organise the police and re-establish order.

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICAN FILIBUSTERING.
FBRREIRA'S FOLLOWERS DESERTING.

div.p: The authorities of the German frontier have received orders to disarm Beers who are trying to enter the Colony from the Cape. (Reuter)
Ferreira's followers are deserting. Only 12 remain with him now. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HOUSE OF LORDS.
"PRACTICAL ADVICE" WANTED.

div.p: Mr. Birrell, speaking at Hanley characterized the House of Lords as a Committee of the Tory Club. If they continued to decline to accept measures, the Government might be forced to ask the country for some practical advice. (Reuter)

div.head:
STATE OF RUSSIA.
OUTRAGES AND EXECUTIONS.

div.p: Terrorist outrages, drumhead court martials, and executions continue to take place in Rus daily. (Reuter)
Dr. Nansen has received the Grand Cross of the Victorian Order. King Haakon has appointed King Edward an Honorary General.
(Reuter)
The grant of the firman for the extension of the Smyrna-Aidin Railway shows that the Porte considers the question of the increase of Customs does as settled. (Havas)

div.p: The directors of the Land and Mortgage Co. of Egypt have declared an interim dividend at .the rate c f 10 per cent, per annum for the had year ended September 3o.

div.head: Transport
div.p: The. transport Sicilia, which arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Southampton and sailed at 4 p.m. for Bombay, had on board 1,120 officers and men and their faonües.

div.head: Tourists.
div.p: The French tourists who are visiting Cairo nüder the auspices of the Revue Gét érale des Sciences are leav'ng Cairo on Monday for Port Said, where they will embark on the yacht He do France for J ffa.

div.head: Telegraphic News
div.p: The news of General Rogers' death, tele graphed yesterday by Renter, wae a week old, the distinguished soldier having died on Thursday week He was buried od Monday last at Bathwick cemetery.

div.head: Khédivial Sporting Club.
div.p: With the kind permission of the officer commanding, tin band of the Inniskiliing Dragoons will play at the Khédivial Sporting Ciob, Ghezireh to day RDd on Monday. The band ot the R'yal Inniskiliing Fusiliers will 'fflay at the flub on Tuesday.

div.head: The Banknote Robbery.
div.p: As will be seen by a notice in our columns, a reward of £100 is offered to any person giving information which may lead to the recovery of the L.E. 3,900 in National Bank notes which were recently lo«t in the post (ffinein a registered letter addressed to Mr. N. D. Lambrop, Benba.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Bank.
div.p: The directors of the Anglo Egyptian Bank have declared a dividend of 10. per share for the half-year ended August 31, making 15 per cent, for the year. Toe directors propose to add £50,000 to the reserve fond, raising it to £550,000, and £10,(00 to the pension fond, carrying forward £29,000.

div.head: A Fast Run.
div.p: The Elle man'Ci'y liner S.S. City of Glasgow, which left Liverpool ou October 12, with a fall complement cf passengers, arrived at Calcutta on November 7, having made the run in twenty five days, excluding the passage of the Suez Canah- This is one of the fastest runs made between Great Britain and Calcatta.

div.head: Beyram.
div.p: The commencement of the feast of Beyram was announced at Alexandria yesterday at 3 p.m. by the filing ot 21 guns from Fort Kaid Bey. The Khédivial yacht Mabronssa, the Coastguard boats, and the merchant ships in harbour, as well as Ras el Tin ligh'house and Kom el Nadonra signal statior, were dressed rainbow fashion in the afternoon.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre.
div.p: Pressure on oar space prevents us giving an account of the splendid performaLC3 of Daudet's "3apbo" by Mme Jane Hading last evening. To-night, the great actress will appear in ' Li Ms! .re des Forges" ("The Ironmaster") and to-morrow will give her fiual performance before proceeding to Cairo, where she appears at the Abbas Theatre on Monday in "La Princesse Georges."

div.p: Messrs. H. de Vries and B mtigny, st:ck and, share brokers of Cairo, publish a daily circular which briefly and clearly exposes everything relating to shares and cotton. This bulletin is of great utility to all desirous of following easily and closely the actual movement of the market. The circular, which also contains considerable financial information, is tent gratis on application.

div.head: Minieh Agricultural Show.
div.p: It having become k- own that tiny were to bear the expenses of the agricultural show to be held at Minieh on the 29th inst., the inhabitants of Miuieh Moudirieh subscribed L.E. 2,500 for that purpose and remitted the amount to the Khédivial Agricultural Society, which is in charge of the arrangement» for the show. The society, however, only accepted L.E. 500 of the money, and refunded the balance to the subscribers. The Khedive will probably atte .d the opening of the show.

div.head: Seamen's Home.
div.p: A very enjoyable concert was provided Iasi Dightat this excellent institution. The Rev H. P. Rsid presided, and Messrs. Hughes,'1 Thompson, and H. and W. Tookey delighted their auditors with a choice repertoire, eluding pieces which were original. The piano . accompaniments were played by Mr. Wood, who is a local celebrity, and whose execution is greatly appreciated. We must not forget Captain Dingle, to whose organising skill the success of the evening is also due.

div.p: The following appears in yesterday's General Orders ' The attention of officers and other ranks who own dogs is drawn to the decree of II E. the Governor of Cairo, dated 23rd Nov-mber, 1905, which degs when in the i-treots mast either be muzz ed Further, they must, wear a metal plate the nuine and address of their owner. The C mm codant, Cairo City Police, has no'ified thaf ntringent orders have been given to the police on dog service to arrest all dogs seen in the streets, etc., which dc not fulfil the above conditions."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
TO-DAY'S HEY HAM DECEPTION.
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Has el Tin Palace from Mont»zah at 8 o'clockk this morning and held a reception on the occasion of Beyram and his approaching departure to Cairo.

The 3rd Battalion Egyptian Army, stationed at Ras el Tin barracks, was drawn up in two lines in front cf the Palace, and paid military honours to the Khedive's visitors, who were many in number and included the Princes of the Khédivial Fanrly, the Ministers, the Advisers, the Under Secretaries of State, Ghaz; Mukhtar Pasha, members of the Consular Oorp, the heads of the religious denominations. the mspistracy, heads of State Administrations, officers of tl e Egyptian Army and the Army ( f Occupation, native notables, etc.
This afternoon at 4 o'c'ock the Khedive will return the visit of Ghazi Mnkhtar Pasha at No. 3 Palace. After visiting the Ottoman High Commipsioner his Highness will proceed to Montazih Palace.
It is expected hisHighue^s will leave Montazah this evening for Mariout, whence he will go on a few days' trip in the desert.
Invitations have been issued by the Alex andria Gouvernorat to be present at Moharrem Bey station at the departure of the Khedive for Cairo at 7.30 a.m. on the 24th inst.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The King has grantei permission to the following gentlemen to wear decorations in connection with the Imperial Ottoman Order conferred npon them by the Khedive of Egypt in recognition of valuable services :— Messrs. Arthur Adamson, Director of Works, Irrigation Service, in the Public Works Department of the Egyptian Government ; William Richard Williams, Inspector, Third Circle of Irrigation ; Percy Marmadnke Tottenham, Inspector, Fourth Circle of Irrigation ; John Danvers Waghorn, Director of the As^iont Barrage ; Claude Augustin de Cosson, Director of Works, Special Buildings, Upper Egypt; and Frank Pears Watson, Chief Engineer, Special Buildings, Lower Egypt.

div.head: THE GRAND MUFTISHIP.
div.p: The "Misr" learns that the Government intends to appoint Shaikh Mohamed Bekhet, of the Cairo Mehkeonh, as Grand Mufti of Egypt, in place of Sheikh Ashour El Sidfi; bat ' lie report lacks confirmation.

div.head: AL AZHAR
div.p: According to "Al Abram," the Khedive has finally appointed Sheikh Hafonna El Nawawi as Chancellor of A1 Azhar University, which position he bad already filled several years ago. It is also said that Sheikh Mohamed Shakir will hold the post of vice chancellor of the University.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
div.p: The annual meetings of the consulting engineers of the Suez Canal Company were held last week in Paris. According to the "Times" report-, the British representatives were Mit L. F. Vernon-Harcourt, Emeritus Professor of Civil Engineering at University College, London, and Mr. A.G.Lyster, chief engineer of the Liverpool Dock and Harbour Board. Among the directors of the company present were Prince fl'Arenberg, Comte Charles de Lesseps, and Sir Henry Austin Lee.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE
div.p: The wrestling bouts at the Abbas Theatre last night were all interesting. Petlinger beat Sohackmann after a long struggle, daring which the judge and those members of the audience who had obtained seats on the stage ran some risk of beiug charged or seized by the excited wrestlers. Mehîmed the African, who allowed remarkable agility, beat his German oppotie:, who seemed rather out of conditior, while Vanderfce'g (Holland) mace a very plucky fight against Limousin, but was in the end worsted by the superior science of the elder man. The sensation of the evening was to have been the bout between Salama the Egyptian and Carl Cyli, the soi disant English wrestler. The Egyp'un wod the bout with considerable ease, his weight and strengih easily enabling him to overpower a much lighter adversary, though Cylis did not seem satisfied with the judge's decision. But almost before a sportsmanlike audience had time to applaud the victor a diminutive gentleman arrayed in a tarboosh and a suit of dittos rushed in front of the stage and informed the audience with much gesticulation that the £5') had never been deposited in the National Bank as such that he and his friends had nover cffVed the suit, and that altogether the public h id been hoaxed. We also understood the gentleman to say that he was not going to pay anybody anything. The audience, so far from being annoyed, indulged in loud at 1 o'clock.

div.head: ENGLAND IN EGYPT
ATTITUDE NOT AGGRESSIVE.
div.p: In the course of his speech at the Guidhall, on the occasion of the Lord Mayor's Banquet, the Marquis of Ripon said : * Yon will, perhaps, remember that there was a question of honndarips in the East as between Turkey and Egypt. That difficulty has happily passed awby. a satisfactory and honourable arrangement has been arrived at. ând I believe the whole que8tion has been settled upon a permanent basis. Our position has been throughout, in this matter not to allow the position of Egypt to be in any way impaired or infringed, but I need scarcely say that we have not assumed an aggressive attitude."

Thus the London ' Tribune' Lord Ripon spoke briefly on the Tabah incident, but much graver than that passing cor fliot with the Sultan was the unrest in Egypt which grew out of it. It is probable that the alarm which the revival of the national movement excited was much exaggerated. On calm consideration it has turned out to be neither a wave of fanaticism nor a beginning of revolt. We gather from a reaseurirg official Dotice, which was recently issued to tourists, that the unrest which was thought to be so considerable that Parliamentary discussion was inadvisable is now beld to be so ionocent that no tourist need dread it. It remains what it always was, the demand of a population more prosperous, more enlightened, more happy than of old, for some recognition in the shape of self-government of the moral and material progress which it has made onder English guidance. The beginnings of a more popular policy in education and the admis-«ion (fat least one Liberal Egyptian to high office go to show that Lord Cromer is not entirely opposed to this demand. If this tendency can be maintained and accelerated the painful Denishwai incident may prove to have been the turning-point between a policy of coercion which must have led to disaster and a new effort towards conciliation and self- government.

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS
APPEAL FOR SUPPORT.
div.p: In our issue of Thursday we drew the attention of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the shipping agents to the cruel manner in which, according to our informant (the accuracy of whose [statements we have no occasion to doubt) cattle arriving by ships at Alexandria are landed. We do not wish to recur to there instances in particular at present ; similar complaints bave been made to as on more than one occasion and we have already dealt folly with them from time to time. We await the results of our article in full confidence that the S.P.C.A. will .investigate the matter and take the necessary steps to put an end to any oraelty in so far as it lies in their power. We take this opportunity, however, to once more impress upon the public, residential and visiting, the claims of the society to that financial aid which is absolutely necessary for the satisfactory execution of its laudable work. Though the subscriptions which the society receives annually famish sufficient fands for extensive operations, there is and always will be ample scope for further extension and, moreover, well-filled coffers would guarantee a more perfect supervision of the work of the junior officials.

All who know this country have been struck by the cruelty.-with which the na'ive labourer, the street loafer, the driver, the donkey boy, in fact, the lower classes generally, treat ani mais, but we are afraid that with many per sons the feeling of pity is in a very short time succeeded byapa'hy. Tourists who visit this country comment lengthily upon the brutality of the native lower classes, b it the instances in which their sympathy assumes a tangible form are far too rare. Ouce more we appeal to the wealthy to open their purse-strings for the alleviation of the pain of animals incapable of self aid, and to those who are unable to subscribe significant sums we say "give yonr mite." The society is peifmning a great work which is in every degree dependent upon public generosity.

Support, too, can be given to the society by not only checking bat also by drawing the attention of the police to every case of cruelty witnessed. In ro far as oar experience goes, the police are quite willing to stop any sort of cruelty, and, if our insists, to arrest any person guilty of maltreatment, and in this we believe they are encouraged by the society by the promise of a small reward. It is a very simple matter to point out to a shawish an animal who is being driven while suffering from sores, an overloaded cart, cases of beating, and this like, and by each interference one contribute invaluable aid to the society.

div.head: THE ARAB REVOLT
div.p: Owing to the failure of the Imperial Government to send reinforcements, the revolt in the Assyr, between the Yemen and the Hedjsz, starting from Beni Shehr, has tread towards Mecca. Revolution is now general in the Assyr, and the movement is in sympathy with a renewal of hostilities on the part of the Wahabites. A huge military expedition, a serious undertaking for an exhausted war chest, can alone save the Turkish position.

div.head: Hellenic Agency.
div.p: It is M. Papadiamantoponlo, ex-Consul General at Salonica, and not M. Scotties, of Alexandria, who is to succeed M Philon as Hellenio Consul-General here. M. Papadia- mantopoulo is expected early next week to take op his new office. He has been entrusted with missions on several occasions by the Hellenic Government, especially in Crete, and accomplished them satisfactorily.

div.head: Public Health at Mecca.
div.p: Messages from Mecca report that the 25,000 pilgrims now in the Holy City are in good health.

div.head: Bulgaria and Egypt
div.p: Mr. Boris Michailowsky, of the Balgarian Agency here, has been appointed first seoret- j ary of the Bulgarian commercial agency at , Cairo. Mr. Michailowsky was lately in charge of the Balgarian Agency at Athens. During his stay here Mr. Michailowsky made many friends, who will miss him very much.

div.head: Bank of Athens.
div.p: I am informed that the Bank of Athens intends opening branches at Mansourab, Port Said, Lefkosia (Cyprus), and Marseilles.

div.head: Russia and Egypt.
div.p: The Black Sea Navigation Co., which lately concluded with the Bulgarian Railways a tariff of through rates between Russian ports and Bulgarian towns, is to extend its service by a new line to Egypt, v'â the Balgarian ports, which will thus be put into direct communication with Egypt. The commission appointed by the Balgarian Black Sea Steamship Line, to fit in with the exteusion to Egypt, ha* completed its labours, and its recommendations are to be examined at an extraordinary meeting of the shareholders prior to their being entered this extension is not to exceed Fr. 400,000.

div.head: WARNING TO TOURISTS.
div.p: We extract the following letter addressed to the editor of the "New York Herald" (Paris edition) "a titre de ouriosité"
determined last year, after a long sojourn in Egypt, to send this season a word of warning to my country women who intend to go there.

It concerns the deceptions practised upon travellers, and the false information given order to made them spend money, and spent it as the guides and dragomen wi-h. Foi instance, I was told in Cairo that I coaid no1 go to the Oasis of the Fayoum, unless with gaide and tents to camp out. I had given uj the trip on this account, being alone with mj maid. By accident, I found out that I conk go by train from Cairo to Medinet-el Fayoun in three honrp, and seeing that I could rial it and get back to Cairo that evening, the*e was no hotel, I started. I found a fairly comfortable hotel at Medinet, Hotel Karoun, where the proprietor spoke English, and pro videl guides, donkeys or oarriages for the1 excursions. I spent three days at Medinet and regretted much I could not stay a week at the qaeer little hotel in tents at Lake Moeris.

I could give many, instances like these, at each stopping place, for a moat powerful ring owds the country apparently, and the traveller only finds out the things he might have done when his time is up and his money wasted.

I will add that a guide is ot little use in the city of Cairo, and a walk through the native part of it far more interesting it one is without one. In the bazaars you pay doable and yon are hurried through the mofques and palaces. Not to mention the false and cooked up information poured out on you, which distracts from the contemplation of some of the most interesting and beautiful things now left in the world.L. P. M.
Savannah, Ga.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
CUSTOMS RETURNS FOR OCTOBER.
div.p: Our total imports for October represented L.E 2,721,461, an increase of L.E. 216,911 over those for October, 1905. The total for the ten months ended on Ootober 31 is L.E. 19,186,097, a rise of L.E. 1,95°,688 from L.E. 17,221,409, which was the total for the same period last year. Of the total of L.E. 2,721,461 for last month, Great Britain's share was L.E. 886.447, Germany, L.E. 145,383 ; Anstria-Hongary, L E. 197,280 ; France, L.E. 299,486; Greece, L.E. 27,253; Italy, L.E. 134,523 ; Turkey, L.E. 388 264 ; Russia, L.E. 39,263 ; "other countries," L.E. 603,562.

The chief items of import during the month were: live stock, L.E. 148.795; cereals, L.E. 414,178 ; coal and wood, LE. 342,351 ; tex tiles, L.E. 753,406 ; metals, L.E. 466,853. In coal, metals, and textiles, Great Britain has the lion's share, beiüg respectively L.E. 14^,820, L.E. 194,957, and LE. 419 594; cotton yarns fignring for L.E. 313,222. In live stock and animal produoe, as also in cereals, vegetables, and flour, Turkey con tributes g largely, these being respectively LE. 102,491 and L.E 138.950, her.exports of dried traits alone totalling L.E. 58.641. France the greatest amount of alcoholic liquors and oils, sending as much as L.E.23,637. The tobacco import bill for the month was L.E. 56,297, beaded by Turkey, which sent L.E. 26,090 worth of leaf tobacco, the remainder of her consignment being of tumbek'. Greece followed suit with LE./f7,279 of leaf. Great Britain's tobacco ^exports to Egypt, though small, are chiefly manufactured ; there is, we believe, a growing demand for this home article, which we hope to see met.

Turning now to exports, the total for October shows the notable increase of L.E. 1.060,183 over the same month last year, being £2[999,257. Still more striking is this inorease when compared with the total of September this year, when the total vas L.E. 908,336. Most of tlrs export went to Great Britain, which took L.E. 2.025,003, her imports of cotton amounting to L.E. 1,682,963 out of a total of L.E. 2,413,640. It is this factor which largely contributed to the remarkable inorease, and that this is going to be a record season is shown by the increase of L.E. 938.813 over the exports of last October.
In September, this year, the total exports of cotton were L.E 666,645, of which nearly half went to Great Britain, or L.E. 374,159, a

Cotton seed is also an important item, exports being valued at L.E. 329 339, of which Great Britain took L.E 286,091 ; in this also there was a rise ot LE. 155,988 over last year. Oar September shipments of the seed were value» at L.E. 99,467 ; L.E. 76,054 worth went Great Britain.
For the ten months ended on October 31 the total exports from E^ypt were L.E 26 642.168. as against LE. 14.817,247 for the like period Ust year, a lisa of L.E. 1.824 921

Our coal import hi 1 for October was L.E 12\969, the value of 171,289 tons, ss agains L.E. 116,042 and LE. 1 .'0,673 last year. I addition to this, there were 78,9*8 tons o British co*l in transit worth L.E. 64,443. Ou total imports for the ten months ended th( 30th Oîtober were 1,067.260 tous, valued ai L.E. 801,352, as compared with 934,865 tom and L.E. 697,763 in 1905.

div.head: SAN STEFANO ROBBERY-
BOOTY FOUND AT MONTAZAH.
div.p: The management f t San Strfano Casino Las been somewhat perplexed oil ate at the mysterious disappearance of sundry articles tf silver ware, such as knives and forks, and had it not been for an accidental discovery, somewhat remote from the shores of Ramleb, the pilfering ight have gone on apace.

The coastguard authorities had recently had their suspicions on the tribesmen of the Waled AH, who are encamped in the desert beyond Montazih, and a raid was made for hashish which was believed to he concealed in the tents. Instead of this, however, the police officer came across a silver spoon, and his suspicions aronsed he asked the tent dwellers how it came there. The reply was that it had been found on the road.

This, however, did not satisfy the effioer, and a farther eearch revealed a hoard of similar articles bearing letters which betrayed their otigin. The articles in question have teen identified by Mme Landauer, but unfortunately they represent only a part of wbat has been stolen.

How these articles came to be spirited cut to the desert is a mystery ; for the Bedouins have little truck with so fashionable an hotel. The only possible explanation is the conivance of the native domestics.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly came down to Alexandria from Cairn yesterday evening in order to attend the Khédivial reception at Rasel* Tin Palace this morning After paying a visit to Makhtar Pasha his Highness returned to Cairo by the noon train to day.
Princess Kh&digé H-tnem, sister of the Khedive, came down to Alexandria from Cairo to-day to attend the Khedivah's Beyram reception.
Kaimakam Parker Bey, Governor of the Sinai, leaves for Suez this evening.
Mr. Douglas Dunlop, Adviser to the Ministry of Public Instraotnn, has arrived from Cairo, and is staying at the New Viotoria Hotel. Ramleb.
Brigadier General Daingerfield Barker, who is at present at Milan, will visit Venice and o4her Italian cities, and will subsequently proceed to Palestine, Egypt, and Spain before returning to Pari3.

Major H. W. R. Ricardo has been selected to sacceed Mejor G. E. E. G. Cameron as Adjutant of the Royal Hospital, Chelsea. Formerly second in command of the 17th Lancers, Major Ricardo took part in the Sudan Campaign of 1898, through which he ferved with the Egyptian Cavalry, being present in several engagements, inclnding the hattleof Khartonm. He went to Soath Africa with his regiment in 1900. and waspreseutatthe aotion near Vet River, Bethlehem, Wittebergen, and nnmeron8 other affairs, for whieh he received the medal with four clasps. Retiring in May, 1903, with the rank of Major, he shortly afterwards became a member of the Hon. Corps of Gentlemen at A ^8.
Mr. James G. Carter, U. S Consul at Tamatave, Madagascar, arrived here this morning en route for his post.

We are pleased to announce the engagement, which took place at Floreooe last^month, of Mile Lili Haicali8, daughter of the late Haioalis Pasha, and sister of M. John Haioalis, to the Marqais Alfredo Lavaggi.
Mr. and Mrs. E. J. R'ohmoad are staying at Mena House for Beyram.
Mr. A.J. Michaelidcs, the will known gentleman jockey, left Sidi Gaber yesterday with his family to spend the wintet season at Helonan.

The E.T.C. football olnb will be greatly weakened by the impending departure of Mr. Neville Ames, their dashing inside right. Their loss, however, will be Aden's gain, as Mr. Ames proceeds there on Taesday. We wish him every saccess in his new station.

Among the latest arrivals at the New Victoria Hotel. Ramleh. we notice : Capt. and Mrs. M. C. Dixon, Miss L. Dixon, Master Dixon. Mr. B. 8. Thomas. Capt. R. T. Dixon, Mr. E. Graf. Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Bearcrott, Mr. James Watson, Hussein Siufi Pasha, Mr. W. R. Smith, Mrs. and Miss Gorra, Mr. Douglas Dunlop, Mr. G. Rankewitz, Mr. and Mrs. P. Valleri, Miss M. Gabriel.

div.head: ROYAL DUBLIN FUSILIERS.
div.p: A correspondent writing from Egypt to the "Army and Navy Gszette" says :—"Among recent arrivals is Major Bromilow, who has joined the 1st Batn. Royal Dublin Fusiliers here from the 2nd Batn. in Ireland on appointment as second in ocmir'-ud. —Brevet Major Fetherstonhangh is posted to the battalion on rejoining for regimental duty.—Lieat. Stirling, D.S.O., of this battalion, has been taken on to the strength of the Egyptian Army for employment.—The Royal Doblins are going strong onder the command of Lieut. Col. Chapman, who was fortunate in taking them over in such good condition from his predecessor."

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: The fourth annual general meeting of the Saint Andrew Football Club was held on Thursday evening, 15th inst., in the committee- room of the British Club, when there was a good turn-oot of a embers. Mr. J. L. Tolloch presided, and in the course of his remarks dealt with the club's past record, its present satisfactory financial position, and its future prospects. A good season is anticipated for 1906-7. Regret was expressed at the club being at present without a playing pitch, but it is hoped that a suitable piece of land will be found later in the season. The olnb opens the new season to day with a match versus the King's Royal Rifles F.C. at Rs-el-Tin, when the following players wifi tike the field, viz , Messrs. Dawson, Curtis, Tamvaco, Ecclestone, Edward, Metzger, Rofe, Jones, Kerr, Cassels aod Tolloch. The teams will kick off at 3.30 p.m. A good game should be witnessed.

div.head: HOPE FOR THE SICK
A VICTIM OF LA GRIPPE
div.p: Mrs. Henrietta A. S. Marsh, 709 W. 16th St., Los Angeles, Cal., President Woman's Benevolent Ass'n, writes :
suffered with Im grippe for seven weeks, mod nothing I could do or take helped me until / tried Peruna,

I felt at once that 1 had at last secured the right medicine and I kept steadily improving. Within three weeks I was folly restored, and I am glad that I gave that truly great remedy a trial. I will never be without it again."

In a letter dated August 81,1904, Mrs. Marsh says : "I have never yet heard the efficacy of Peruna questioned. We still use it. I traveled through Kentucky and Tennessee three years ago, where I found Peruna doing its good work. Much of it is being used here also."-—Henrietta A. S. Marsh.
Address Dr. Hartman, President of The Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio.

For special directions everyone would read "The Ills of Life " a copy, of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty five shillings.

div.head: REVENUE COMMERCIALE
Cotons
div.p: Par sa tenue durant la semaine qui vient de|; finir, Dotre marché a donné raison à ceux qui depuis quelque temps, se sont montrés! sceptiques sur la réussite des tentatives de hausse qu'4 tout instant on cherche de faire et même sur la possibilité, à me ins d'une repripe sérieuse et stable rn Amérique, de maintenir nos cours à lenr niveau actuel. Il y a quelque chose de factice en l'air, qui fausse la situation et entrave les efforts des haussiers, et il n'est pas d.ffioile de s'en apercevoir quand on voit l'empressement outré que montrent beaucoup de spéculateurs à vouhir réaliser, soit 6ons l'influence d'une nouvelle quelcoLque, soit dès qu'une occasion plus ou moins propice se présente : Eu somme, il y a trop de petite» msins intéressées et trop! de positions surchargées, qu'on ne demand/! qu'à diminuer, et il est certain que ce n'est pal avec des éléments pareils que l'on peut do mirer sur un marct é en dépit de tontes 1er ciicoDS^aDces contraires. I

Cette appré-iation n'est rfreuent pas dj nature à plaire au parti de la hausse ; mai est-il popsib'e de se soust a're à cette imprec 8ion plutiV pessimiste quard on se trouve er face de mouvements désordonnés c* iume ceui que noun avons eus Vendr< di et Samed derniers % JLe demi tal'ari gagné le prrmiei jour, sans justification suffisante, a é'é perdr en entier le lendemain et l'avance d'égal importance qu'on a cherché de consolider depuis Jors menace tout bonmmcnt de 8f liquéfier de nouveau, et ei noua voulions résn mer tontes le* Duc'uatit n« de la semaine nous trouvons que l'unique résultat obtenu consiste en une ba sse de 3/32 de tallari, la clôture de ce soir pour le Novembre ayant en lieu à 17 15/39. ,
Maintenant, malgré ce que nous vfnone de dire, il ne faut pas croire qre le champ est (ibre pour la baisse ; non, mille fois non, mais

nous sommes, après tout, à un niveau exagéré qui ne pourrait que faire du mal pour l'avenir, tandn q dnu peu de modération ne saurait que nous piéparer une excellente fioale. La consommation de l'égyptien est incontestable ment forte cette année mais, malgré son importance, les spécialités que l'on tait avec dos cotors ne seraient jamais suffisantes pour absorber notre récolte en entier et, par consé quent, comme noos l avons dit à maintes re prise1*, il restera toujours un assez gros surplus dont il faut absolument faci iter le \ lacement, d'autant plus que notre récolte sera supérieure à tontes celles q* e nous avons eues par le pas>é.

Or, le seul débouclé qu'il y aurait pour qet exiédeut consisterait dans sou emploi jour nélanger aveo les anéricaiDB défectueux ou pour rfmp'acement les américains longue soie qui sont rares cette année, mais pour ce d* rnier ol jet, la question du prix et de l'écart entre le» deux qualités viendrait im- néiiatfment en ligne de compte et ce point mérite de ne pas être oublié. L'année dernière, la filature a eu recours au bon américain pc tir combattre la spécula'ion de notre plac*», mais o'est le bon marché de l'un par rapport à l'autre qui lui a permis de le faire ; aussi, et aveo beaucoup plus de raisoD, l'égyptienne pourrait venir à suppléer au manque du bon américain que s'il est à des prix raisonnables ou abordable?, car, en définitive, il ne s'agit pas, daD8 oe deraier cas, de nécessité absolue, mais simplement de posai bilité éventuelle.

Encore une fois, tout est en faveur de l'égyptien cette année, mais ne perdons pas de vue non plus qae nous allons avoir forcé ment un peu de ralentissement dans les exportations à partir dû mois prochain, aprè tout ce qui à été expédié depuis le common cement de la réjolte, que notre stook ne fait qu'augmenter, qu'à partir du 15 Décem bre la période des fêtes et des bilanB de fin d'année commencera à Lire sentir son influence et que tout cela réuni n'est pas fait pour nous valoir des marobés en feu ! !

Et pour conolure, soy« ns sages et laissons au niveau de 17 tallaris pour Mars le soin d» noua attirer de nouveau et d'une façon géné raie la demande et De nous amusons pas 4 la limiter aveo nos idées de vouloir imptser le cours de 18 et plus. Ceoi pourra venir par la suite quand on aura à décompter aveo le dé couvert ; mais, pour atteindre ce but, il faut commencer d'abord par assurer l'écoulemen de la marchandise au dehors.

La nouvelle récolte s'est très bien maint* nue et l'écart entre les deux Novembre, 1906 et 1907, n'est plus que de 3/4 de tallari. Au fond, l'activité n'a pas été énorme, mais il y a eu constamment de la dtpiantje, tant spécula tive q-ie commerciale, pour la pampagre pro chaîne, tandis qu'en général les vendeurs en blanc sont de plus en plos réservés, ün signale de nouvelles affaire* aveo la filature, assez coméquentes, sur la base des cours actuels, poor embarquement Novembre 1907 à Janvier 1908,

Pour ôe qui est des reports sur la récolte actuelle, ils ne font que s'élargir : De Novem bre à Mars, nous sommes à 11/16 de tallari , de Mars h Ma:, il y a 1/2 tallari et entre Mai et Juillet il existe 3/8 et il est positif que le dernier motn'est pas dit! Combien avions-nous raison quand noue ayons donné le conseil d'acheter la nouvelle récolte et de vendre les mois rapprochés de l'a* ejennei

Les nouvelle* d'Amérique, si elles n'ont pas é é bien întén «sautes, en debers de celle annonçant l'obligation cù s'est trouvé le grand leader de la hausse, de cetto année, de devoir liquider sa position, ODt été par contre assez nombreuses : Tout a été cêb'é pour produire la hausse, soit, killing frost général mais se réduisant eu définitive à un peu de neige dars 1'Alabama, diminution de recettes en vue, réveil de la demande et achats énormes de la part de la filature ; réduction des estimations précédentes de la récol'e, mais tout cela n'a servi qu'à produire une reprise limitée et, en apparence, de courte durée! Et à notre avis, au lond, nos bous amie les Amérioans n'en savent pas plus loi g que noua et up visent qu'4 nous attirer à faire de r.cuvellep affairep, pour let-i I plus grand profP, quitte* à ne nous indiquer * nno tendance vraie que quand le prochain rapport d'égreDage, ou peut è re seulement nuhod'e rapport du Bureau d'Agricilture du H Décembre seront venus les fixer sur les pro- b^b li'és de la récol e Ce qui semble acquis pour le momeuS ce sont les deux p< iot- que la consommatiop sera grande et qu'il y aura pas mal de mauvais cotou ; quant aux prix, dans ces condition?, ils ne sont pasélevée, mais bien susceptibles d'une forte hausse, dès que le parti de la bai sp, q' i est toujours en train de peser la situation, aura fini ebb raobats ou changé son fusil d'épaule.

Par moments, l'activité sur notre marché du disponible a laissé à désirer, mais dans l'en- Bemblo le mouvement d'affaires pendaut la semaine a été assez satisfaisant. Dans tous les cas, la semaine finit oalme.
Quant aux prix, ils ont fiüi par revenir à leur point de départ de vendredi dernier, aussi bien pour le Mit Affifi que pour les proveoances Haute-Egypte et Fnyoum.

Les qualités inférieures de Goodfair et au- dessous ont éfé en Lvenr, comme aussi les Abassi et les Joannoviob. Ces deux derniers genres sont de pins en plus rares sur le marché et ne cessent *d'être recherchés, et, dans ers conditions, il n'y a rien d'étonnant 4 ce que leur va'enr ait subi une hausse senrible, soit de 5/8 à 7/8, pour les premiers et de 1 1/4 à
Cette semaine il n'y a pas ea d'enohère aux Domaines pour insuffisance d'arrivages, mais pour jeudi prochain il y aura one vente assez ronde.

Les exportations de la hnitaiuq ont atteint balles 36.COO, contre balles 30.S00 en 1905 pour la même période, mais, tant à cause des fêtes indigènes que du ralentissement de la demande pour Manchester, les pronostics pour la semaine prochaine sont pour des quantités moine fortes, à moins que le règlemeut d'une grande partie des suspens en douane ne vienne les grossir.

Sauf pour un ou deux jours, Liverpool s'est tenu dans les petits chiffres pour les Egyptiens disponibles. Quant 4*ce quiiest des prix, il y a de la baiese sur le spot, le folly good fair étant coté 9 3/8. L98 futurs, au contraire, ont gagné an peu de terrain, la olôtare de oe soir ayant en lieu à 9 14/64 poor le Novembre, soit one hausse de 3/64. Le Mars vauth 60/64.

La filature n'a pas besoin de recourir trop au marché de Liverpool, les expéditions direo tes qui loi sont faites d'ici étant pins que suffi santés pour l'alimenter et pour lui permettre de se reconstituer un stock ; mais oe qai est surprenant, c'est l'énorme écart existaut entre nos oours et cenx du grand marché anglais poor les futurs, surtout sar les mois éloignés.

list.item: est absolument ridioule de constater dès le débat de la campagne des différences de * 1/4 à 1 1,2 tallari !

div.p: L'importance des ventes en disponible amé ricain à Liverpool prouve qu'il y a du vrai daDg l'assertion que la filature est de Donvean aux achats ; dans tons les oa6, depuis deux on trois jours, c'est à 12,000 balles environ qae les ventes s'élèvent

En ce qai concerne les prix, le spot, après avoi#fléchi à 5.50 est remonté à 5.75, pour finir à 5.85, oe qai Lit qae la hausse sur ce chef s'é'ève à 10 points en tout. Les faturs ont beaucoup fluctué et clôturent à 5.54 pour le Janvier Février et à 5.60 pour le Mai-Jain, soit pspectivement 21 et 17 points de hausse.

L'Amérioaiu monte rapidement depuis den ou trois jours. à capse de l'existence d'an corner sur le Novembre Décembre. C'esf; la denrière nouvelle reçue d'une paaisep de Liverpool généralement bien jnforqigç,
Graines do Coton,

Les recettes sont toujours satisfaisantes, mais d'autre part aussi l'importance des besoins poor les embarquements courants ne cessent de maintenir la demande yive et suffisante poor tout absorber presque. Le fajt est que les exportations dépassent les provisions et que t'est 4 cette oirooDstacoe que noos devons le maintien de* prix 4 un niveau platôt élevé par rapport aux contrats. Le cours de olôtare de ce matin a été de PT. 66.

Les suaires en contrats ont été très res treintes pendant la semaine et c'est à la réserve de la spécniarion que re fait est dû. Au plus bss o'est 4 P.T. 66 3/4 que nous avons é é et, comme c'ôture, c'est à P.T. 63. 30 q» e les 3 mois ont fini aiij'iurd'hui. Le rerort est en diminution, le Février-Mars ne valant q^e P.T. 69 3f>.

De l'AngVerrr, il y ael.ûte senrible dam? la demande, oe qui s'explique facilement après les grosses expéditions de oes trmps derniers. Partout olt est amplement fourni pour le moment et il faut bien donner le temps de digérer en partie oe qui est en route avant de voir la consommation revenir au marché d'nne f »ç îu sérieuse Les dernières cotes ponr Hall sont de £6 13/9 le prompt et £6 12, fl les futurs.
Ce sojr on a cependant parlé d'une reprise d* 2/6 et de 14 proviendrait l'amélioration de notre marohé 4 la dernière heure.
Ni le* Oatports, ni le Continent, n'ont rien fait de nouveau.
Fovea,
Marché nul.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Ou a débuté cette semai» e en plrine effervescence sur les petites valeurs, telles que la D »lta Land, le-» Estâtes, l'investirent, la Sait & Snd*, le Trust, l'CLdinary Khédivial Mail et la Building Lands, qui, ponr la plupart clôturent en avance notable sur la rote de vendredi passé. Il y a eu également une certaine animation en Agricole, Tramways d'Alexandrie, Nile Land et Urbaine. Los S îcreries et les parts de fondateur Comptoir ont donné lieu, surtout ces dernières, à une bonne demande. D'nne façm générale, copendant, la cote, après avoir bénéficié dans son ensemble d'une avance appréciable an début de la semaine, a sobi vers la fin et graduellement une réaction d'ailleurs légère, dûe à des tassemeu^s et à la tendance générale de la spéculation à réaliser. Bref, le marohé finit un peu lourd et cette allure semble appelée à s'accentuer à cause de la coïncidence des fêtes avec l'approche d'une liquidation qui s'annonce comme laborieuse.

C'est malgré tout en hausse que finit la semaine : en effet, sur nne cinquantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cite officielle, 26 environ sont en hausse, 8 seulement en baisse et le reste demeure stationnaire.

L'Agricole gagne 5/32 à 9 25/32, la Natio* nal 1/16 à 27 i/4, la Delta Light 1/16 à 12 1/16, les Tramways 6 fr. les Priv à 193 et 16 fr. les Div. à 350, la Doïra 1/4 à 17 1/4, la Béhéra 1/4 à 43 3/4, la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie 7 francs à 217, la Cassa di Soon to 1 fr. à 241, les Nungovich Hotels 7/16 4 18 5/8, la Nile Land 1/8 à 17 3/8, l'Urbaine 5/32 à 6 29/32, la part de fondateur Comptoir 3£ à 55 sans compter le coupon de £2, la Building Lands 11/32 à 5 11/32, le Crédit Franco- Egyptien)l/16 à 5 9/16 et la BaLqae d'Orient 1 fr. 50 4 131.

Par contre, la Ramleh perd 3/32 4 7 1/32, la Bière du Caire 1 et 2 fr. à 133 et 72, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier 2 fr. et 0 fr. 5 J 4 336 et 271 1/2, la Bai que d'Athènes 0 fr. 50 à 145 1/2. et l'Union Fonoière 1/32 4 6 17/32.

Quant aux petites valeurs, les Mirkets s'avancent 4 27/3, la Sait & S:>da à £6/3, la Dalta Land 4 4 15/32, la Khédivial Mail 4 4 3/4 et 42/6, rinv68tment 4 1 17/32. le Trust 4 1 9/16, les Estates 4 2 3/3, les Splendid Hôtels à 4 3/16, 8t le Cheikh Fadl à 10$.
Tout le reste de la cote demeure stationnaire
Les Egyptian Estate?, qui ont en les fion neurs de cette semaine, clôturent aveo nne avance de 1/16 4 2 13/32.

Le Caire a môme traité oe matin 4 2 7/16, Un dividende intérimaire de 5% vient d'être déclaré par le conseil d'administration de cette Société jusqu'au 30 Septembre dernier; oe dividende est payahle le 91 courant et jours suivants aux bareaux des Egyptian Estates, Sharia Kasr e) Nil, an Caire.

Pour les Hooker on parle d'un ooupon intérimaire de 1 shelling 6 pence, soit 15% sur la 1/2 livre versée. Cette sooiété serait également en pourparlers pour la revente de la propriété qu'elle a récemment achetée aa Crédit Franco-Egyptien Rue el R*ss».fd 4 Moharrem Bey.

N oos apprenons de bonne source que plusieurs sociétés sont en pourpatlerg avec les propriétaires du jardin da Qabbari pour l'achat en partioipatiop de cette propriété. A us rit ôt que l'affaire sera conolue, nous donnerons à nos lecteurs des détails plus circonstanciés.

La Sait and Soda est snr le poÎDt de proclamer son bilan aveo un bénéfice de £80,000. Uq dividende de 7 1/2 % sera distribué aux actionnaires et le surplus sera consacré aux amortissements ou porté 4 la réserve. C'est à cette nouvelle que nous avons é'é les premiers 4 publier qu'il faut attribaer la hausse de ce titre de 25 shellings 4 26/9. Le prix de 27 8helliugs a même été pratiqué dans la matinée.
L'Egyptian Improvements Corporation a acheté de la Compagnie Lyonnaise d'Egypte

la propriété de S.E. le Ghazi Mookhtar Pacha connue sous lo nom de Palais No. 3, au prix de LE. 205,000, (la Compagnie Lyonnaise l'avait elle même achetée pour la somme de LE. 176 000) aux conditions de paiement I suivantes: L.E. 33,125 an comptant, L E.11,875 le 15 janvier 1907 et le reste par versements annuels de 40,000 L E. échelomé* de novembre P 07 à novembre 1910. Cet*e propriété rnesnre environ 230.000 pics oardésv Il a éié créé 215 parts de 100U livrés chacune, représentant le prix d'achat, tous frais compri*. Les souscripteurs de ce* parta auront à opérer un premier versement de L.E. 178 par paît à la souscription, un deuxième de LE. 79 lé 15j-nvier 1907 et le reste sera appelé an fur et h mesure des besoins. Moyennant nue commission de 10 % sur les bénéfices nets, rimprovement8 Corporation se charge du morcellement et de la revente an mieux de la propriété commune sur la base minimum de 20 % de bénéfice net. Le solde des bénéfices sera réparti anx participants an prorata de leurs paris.

L'émission de la Sidi Salem Estates Co. Ld J e»t fixée aux premiers jours de décembre. C'est | le Comptoir National d'Esoompte de Paris qai est chargé de l'émission, tant en Egypte qu'en Angleterre. La totalité des titres, soit environ 103,000, seront offerts 4 la souscription pnbli- . que au prix de £ 4. 5., l'action de £ 4. Les l 5 shellings de prime «errntViorlés 4 la réserve. Quar t 4 la ïépartùion, elleQe fera Au prorata des quantités souscrites. Les titres définitifs seront an porteur aveo timbra anglais ef, par conséqaent, négociables en Egypte et à Londres.

On aura aus doute remarqué que le groupe acheteur de 14 000 feddans de la Béhéra 4 L.E. 38 1/2 lefeddan,le8 transmet sans aucune majoration à la Sidi Silem, en meon ten tant du bénéfice a'éatoire de 25 % que lui donneront les 5,000 parts de fondateurs, après qo^ toutes les chapes auront été payées. C'eat 1A> ou en conviendra, nne part bien modeste dont se contentent rarement nos promoteur.-» de so ciétés. Il n'y a donc auoune charge pécuniaire i sur le capital social, autre quelas frais adminis- j tratifa, le reste devant aller 4 la réserve comme fond de roulement. Déplus, jusqu'au 1er juillet 1908 la SidiSdem n'a pas de charge d'intérêt, puisque les £200 000 de Preference shares allouées 4 la Béhéra 4 5%ne sont que jouissance 4 cette date. En attendant, la nouvelle société jouit des revenus de looations, la plupart de ses terres étant en plein rapport ; et, d'ici 14, elle aora sans doute rédisé d'importants bénéfices sur les reventes, car elle a déjà, aasure- t-on, de nombreuses offres d'aohat à des prix rémonérateura. Ses terrains sont, en effet, très fertiles et admirablement irrigués grâ?e à l'intelligente administration de la Béhéra. Nous n'avons pas besoin de rappeler que les noms les plus connus de la finance égyptienne figurent dans la syndicat de garantie oa dans le conseil d'administration de la Sidi Salem.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
